title: Unsupervised Spiking Neural Network Model of Prefrontal Cortex to study Task Switching with Synaptic deficiency. (arXiv:2305.14394v1 [cs.NE])
abstract: In this study, we build a computational model of Prefrontal Cortex (PFC) using Spiking Neural Networks (SNN) to understand how neurons adapt and respond to tasks switched under short and longer duration of stimulus changes. We also explore behavioral deficits arising out of the PFC lesions by simulating lesioned states in our Spiking architecture model. Although there are some computational models of the PFC, SNN's have not been used to model them. In this study, we use SNN's having parameters close to biologically plausible values and train the model using unsupervised Spike Timing Dependent Plasticity (STDP) learning rule. Our model is based on connectionist architectures and exhibits neural phenomena like sustained activity which helps in generating short-term or working memory. We use these features to simulate lesions by deactivating synaptic pathways and record the weight adjustments of learned patterns and capture the accuracy of learning tasks in such conditions. translated_title: 无监督脉冲神经网络模型研究前额叶皮层中的任务切换和突触缺陷
translated_abstract: 本研究利用脉冲神经网络（SNN）构建了前额叶皮层（PFC）的计算模型，以了解神经元在短时和长时的刺激变化下如何适应和响应任务切换。我们还通过在我们的脉冲体系结构模型中模拟受损状态来探讨 PFC 损伤所引起的行为缺陷。尽管已经存在一些 PFC 的计算模型，但还没有使用 SNN 来建模它们。本研究使用参数接近生物学可行值的 SNN 进行训练，使用无监督的脉冲时序依赖性塑性（STDP）学习规则进行模型训练。我们的模型基于联结主义架构，展现了持久活动等神经现象，有助于产生短期或工作记忆。我们利用这些特点通过关闭突触通路来模拟损伤，并记录学习模式的权重调整和在这种情况下学习任务的准确性。
tldr: 本文介绍了利用脉冲神经网络建立的前额叶皮层计算模型。通过持久活动和无监督学习规则，模拟了任务切换和损伤状态下神经元的响应。实验结果为研究神经元适应和学习提供了新的参考。
en_tdlr: This paper presents a computational model of the prefrontal cortex using spiking neural networks (SNNs) to understand how neurons adapt and respond to task switching, as well as exploring behavioral deficits arising from lesions in the PFC. The model was trained using unsupervised spike timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) learning rule and exhibited neural phenomena like sustained activity. By simulating lesioned states and weight adjustments of learned patterns, the study provides new insights for studying neural adaptation and learning.
